comments.body: `page` should be `ComponentType<any>` instead of `Component` otherwise you get "JSX element type 'â€¦' does not have any construct or call signatures". In other words, as it is now, page is an _instance of_ Component which is not a valid JSX element.

`() => JSX.Element` is going to mean TypeScript rejects any and all props, no? I may be mistaken; the nesting functions here can be a bit hard to reason about. But it seems like `() => JSX.Element` means TypeScript will expect `cb` to be a function that takes a props-less ComponentType and returns a ComponentType with `any` props.

Some changes here are going to bump up against my PR #25775 which attempts to elaborate on this `renderPage` and other `Document` logic, while correcting some bugs introduced in the merged PR that is currently producing conflicts with this one. I'd be curious your thoughts on my PR.

One of the biggest differences I would note is that there are a lot of `[key: string]: any` and `<any>` generics in this PR, which mean that without using, e.g., `as React.ComponentType<MyProps>`, there are going to be a lot of very broadly permissive types generated here without the room for developers to to be precise more precise by passing types to generics. TypeScript won't be able to infer descriptive types and reject, e.g., improperly-passed Props.
One question though, is `renderPage` also used in `App`?
Shouldn't we just make this return the `Promise` instead? @joaovieira

No, it doesn't need to be a Promise necessarily (e.g. the default Document is not). I made these to match the exact signature of the exported classes, but it needs some visiting if sub-classes have to adhere to the same signature as the base class.
